data.title: Integrated Terminal: after exiting PowerShell, a new PowerShell process is lingering
data.body:
while testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6654:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0 alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
- launch integrated terminal
- open Task Manager and remember process id of PowerShell process
- in integrated terminal type 'exit'

Observe:
- integrated terminal becomes empty (and unusable)
- in Task Manager a new PowerShell process exists

data.title: Peek definition should highlihght the line number
data.body:
#6655

Peek definition should highlihg the exact line where the definition is, as in some cases it is not clear as to what exact line the user should be looking at, as in this case:

![screen shot 2016-05-24 at 12 05 22](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/15500188/dbfca74c-21a7-11e6-9ab1-f885b6f0dfbc.png)

data.title: code --unistall-extension: incorrect extension hint.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: code-alpha
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:
1. code --uninstall-extension xxxx

Observe: you get a message:

```
Extension 'xxxx' is not installed.
Make sure you use the full extension id, eg: ms-vscode.csharp
```

The last line would be better:

```
Make sure you use the full extension id, including the publisher, e.g.: ms.vscode-csharp
```

Note that the sample should be ms.vscode-csharp and not ms-vscode-csharp

data.title: `unixLike` is probably better, but inconsistent?
data.body:
Testing #6654 

I am not an expert in unix distributions, and most likely `unixLike` is a better term than `linux`/`osx`, but then we should align and use `unixLike` everywhere.

For example, in `tasks.json` (@dbaeumer) and in `package.json` keybindings contributions we use `linux` and `osx` separately. I am not sure about the `launch.json` (@weinand knows better)

data.title: multi-cursor editing stops working on ubuntu
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

alt+click and column selection "hold shift" + "alt" + "drag" stopped working gradually, now i can't use these at all.

data.title: code --installl-extension needs id which is not very user friendly

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: code-alpha
- OS Version: Linux

To install an extension via the command line you need to know the extensions id which is currently not very visible (only available in the URL). We should either state that this way to install and extension is for pure automation or we should make the feature more user friendly. If I for example type code --install-extension vscode-eslint it should tell me that it knows about dbaeumer.vscode-eslint and if I want to install that plugin.

data.title: Provide option to show all variables in the variables view (when count > 100)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
#6658
- VSCode Version: alpha
- OS Version: os x

Steps to Reproduce:
1. debug the Typescript repo - checker.ts
2. notice that we only show 100 variables, currently there is no way to show all the 900 variables
3. we could offer the user an option to list all variables - for example via a context menu action on the scope

![screen shot 2016-05-24 at 11 57 05](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/15499899/aaa160d0-21a6-11e6-8c6b-3971a628fb37.png)

data.title: integrated terminal: customizing colors through user settings is a bit weird
data.body:
Testing #6654 

Our story so far when it comes to customizing colors is through themes (fyi @aeschli ). Exposing color values in the user settings makes our story inconsistent. e.g. it would be nice to share a theme as an extension that also customizes the integrated terminal, I think the theme format is open-ended to support any amount of additional keys? This also opens the door for requests such as: "I want to change the color of keywords from my settings", which is a path we don't really want to go to

It is also needed that each color would have a light and a dark variant in the settings. if I tweak the values in the light theme, they might not look good when I switch to a dark theme, etc.

data.title: [less] grammar does not highlight variables correctly
Align Open Editor and double arrow down
data.body: #6536 I understand the double arrow down action as an alternative UI to the open editor model. I would - use the prefixes `left`, `right`, and `center` instead of the `~>` sequence - use the same sort order - have the same actions (close)

data.title: Restarting the session is not respecting internal console options
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Alpha
- OS Version: Windows 8

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set the internal console options to openOnSessionStart
2. Launch the session
3. Console is shown as expected
4. Close the console
5. Restart the session

Expected to show the console after restart

data.body:
Testing #6654

data.title: Unfriendly error message from code --install-extension xxxx
data.body:
- VSCode Version: code-alpha
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:
1. code-alpha --install-extension xxxx

You get the following output in the terminal:

```
{ responseText: '{"$id":"1","innerException":null,"message":"The query supplied was not valid, one of the filters contained an error. The fully qualified name MUST contain a \'.\' between the publisher and extension names.","typeName":"Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.Gallery.WebApi.InvalidExtensionQueryException, Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.Gallery.WebApi","typeKey":"InvalidExtensionQueryException","errorCode":0,"eventId":3000}',
  status: 500,
  getResponseHeader: [Function],
  readyState: 4 }

```

data.title: Debug N PHP applications: step over jumps to wrong one
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6160

If you debug multiple PHP scripts at once, and step over a line in the one script, the other script gets revealed in the stackframe view.

data.title: arrow down and dots icon look similar
data.body: #6536 The arrow down icon we now show in the editor header looks like a context menu icon (what the `...`-icon does). I think we need a better icon for that

data.title: Cannot select and scroll beyond the bounds of the viewport in integrated terminal

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6654:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0 alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

to reproduce:
- launch integrated terminal
- run several 'dir' commands to fill the terminal with more lines than visible
- select the lines with the mouse and drag the mouse outside to the viewport to initiate autoscrolling.

Observe: there is no autoscrolling but some other text gets selected.

data.title: [css] word rule should include '-'
Question: Would a wiki page about setting up Intellisense be useful?
data.body:
I recently struggled to get Intellisense working for React.js.

I _think_ I've done it now, so wrote the steps I followed here http://mattdufeu.co.uk/setup-intellisense-vscode-react-js/

Is that correct or am I missing something?

Would something like this be useful on the wiki? I'd be more than happy to create a PR if you think it's useful.

data.title: Intellisense for variable declarations
data.body:
From testing #6656

``` css
:root {
  --foo: // code assist hee


}
```

Code assist could show possible values such as colors, numbers

data.title: Change file association is doing too many things at once and it is not clear what's going on
data.body:
Testing #6657 

IMHO the experience is bad. Clicking this action pops over two message boxes and does an edit in an untracked file that gets autosaved immediately.

IMHO this should show a preview of what it will do before jumping in and doing it and not pop over 2 message boxes! Preferably it would select the new added text.

![association-insane](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/15499131/d515a942-21a2-11e6-8790-fdec374a61eb.gif)

data.title: Feature: add jump to file and line number to debug console output
data.body:
In Chrome (& Edge) console, when something is printed, the file + line number where it occured is printed, and clicking on it opens up the corresponding file at the correct position.

![consolechromefile](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/15499063/842fe33a-21a2-11e6-91b7-6165b3b4f95e.png)

In VSCode you get no such information: the log is printed without any information.

data.title: Feature: support Chrome console extensions in debug console output

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Chrome has been supporting some nice improvements for the console, like:
- console.group('foo'): starts to group console content
- console.groupEnd('foo') stops the 'foo' group

As well as colors inside console text using c-like printf parameters where you may specify css styling:

console.log('Controller: %c%s', 'color:#008;', $route.current.$$route.controller); 

This results in much more readable console output:

![consolechrome](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/15498841/93761fb8-21a1-11e6-8b23-31e70e9d15f3.png)

Since VSCode does not parse these layout/color instructions, the end result is barely readable:

![vscodeconsole](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/15498867/b9f36e34-21a1-11e6-9efd-9f67623e9b6a.png)

data.title: [css] no code assist proposals after variable declaration
